Their argument stems from their low cost, high stability, and ability to perform rapid charge transfer, making them excellent substitutes for noble metal-based catalysts. In this review, CoO and Co3O4 are analyzed from the structural, electronic, and catalytic viewpoints, focusing on their latest design and optimization efforts. The influence of defects, doping, and hybridization with carbon-based supports and metal additives on catalytic activity and stability is highlighted. Besides, the review discusses the influences of oxygen vacancies, cobalt ions in mixed-valence states, and heterostructures on the performance of the materials as a whole. The mechanisms of OER and HER on cobalt oxide-based catalysts are also discussed, emphasizing the electronic structure and reaction pathways these processes involve. The review is supposed to shed light on the processes of manually constructing composite catalysts by integrating CoO and Co3O4 with other materials, so the final products would have differed and enhanced electrocatalytic activity. The review concludes with an outlook on future directions for the development of CoO and Co3O4-based electrocatalysts, including the challenges associated with scaling up their synthesis for industrial applications and the need for further advancements in material engineering to optimize their performance in energy-related processes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cobalt oxide Electrocatalysis Oxygen evolution reaction Hydrogen evolution reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Energy consumption plays a pivotal role in sustaining global economies, and the energy demand continues to surge due to industrialization, population growth, and technological advancements [1,2]. As of 2023, global primary energy consumption has surpassed 600 exajoules annually, with significant contributions from fossil fuels, which still account for over 80 % of the worldwide energy mix [3]. In the United States, the residential and commercial sectors consumed approximately 20.6 quadrillion British thermal units (Btu) in 2023, illustrating the immense energy demand within these sectors [4]. While renewable energy sources such as solar and wind have been expanding, they currently provide only a fraction of the global energy supply, emphasizing the continued reliance on conventional energy sources for the foreseeable future [5,6]. Therefore, transitioning to renewable and clean energy solutions is critical to mitigate the environmental impact of energy consumption [7–9]. Electrocatalysis has become a focal point in developing sustainable energy systems, particularly for hydrogen production via water splitting [5,10]. Cobalt-based materials, including cobalt oxide (CoO) and cobalt sulfide (CoS), have emerged as promising electrocatalysts due to their abundance, low cost, and efficient catalytic properties [11–13]. These materials facilitate the HER and OER, which are essential for hydrogen generation from water [14,15]. The HER involves the reduction of protons to hydrogen gas, a key step in producing hydrogen as a clean energy carrier, while the OER facilitates the oxidation of water to oxygen, a crucial counterpart to HER in water-splitting processes [10,16,17]. Cobaltous compounds, especially the CoO and the cobaltite oxide Co3O4, have emerged as significant materials for electrocatalysis due to their favorable electronic characteristics, wide availability, and inexpensive cost. CoO adopts a simple rock salt structure where cobalt is endowed with an octahedral coordination of oxygen ions [18]. This configuration promotes charge transfer for many types of electrolytic reactions, especially those involving the evolution of hydrogen and the evolution of oxygen. CoO exhibits high conductivity and catalytic activity, which is advantageous for materials needed in processes with serious ionic flux and overtime stability [19]. Unlike, Co3O4 has a spinel structure with cobalt ions found at the two coordination sites; tetrahedral and octahedral. This structure is favorable for both HER and OER because of its mixed valence state (Co²⁺ and Co³⁺) that facilitates electron and active site generation transport [20]. In recent research undertaken on Co3O4, heaping attention has been dispersed onto its use for OER because of rapid oxidation and cobalt having multiple reactive sites leading to remarkable catalytic activity [21]. Further, Co3O4 has been integrated with other materials like carbon-based supports and metal dopants to enhance performance [22]. Given their CoO and Co3O4 pristine structural features, their utility is relevant to many electrocatalytic domains, especially to energy conversion and storage systems. About certain crystal structures and their electronic properties along with catalytic activity, researchers are developing new techniques to improve the efficiency of these materials towards sustainable energy technology [23–25,26]. CoO/Co3O4 heterostructures are critical in improving the efficiency of water splitting for hydrogen production. These materials are highly efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts for both hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) and oxygen evolution reactions (OER), essential for overall water splitting. The advantages of CoO/Co3O4 heterostructures include enhanced electronic properties and optimized reaction kinetics due to their synergistic interaction between CoO and Co3O4 phases. This improves charge transfer and the adsorption of reaction intermediates, lowering the overpotentials required for both reactions. Additionally, the structural benefits such as abundant active sites and defects further contribute to improved performance and stability [27]. Recent studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of these heterostructures, with one showing CoO/Co3O4 nanostructures achieving low overpotentials for water splitting and stable long-term performance [28], while others have explored similar improvements in bifunctional catalytic performance using CoO/Co3O4-based materials under alkaline conditions [29] and in combination with carbon-based materials [30]. This review is distinct in that it traces the latest advances of CoO and Co3O4 materials from their use as electrocatalysts for water-splitting reactions, mainly the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions. The review outlines novel approaches for defect engineering, doping, and hybridization of other materials, including carbon-based supports, which are believed to enhance the performance of these materials. These approaches improve the catalytic activity and durability of cobalt oxides, increasing their usefulness as catalysts compared to precious metals. Furthermore, the review discusses how cobalt oxides electrocatalytic properties may be further enhanced by structural modification through oxygen vacancy introduction and heterostructure development. 2 Crystal structure The structure and properties of cobalt oxide have enabled the synthesis of additional stoichiometric and non-stoichiometric oxides within the past few years [1]. Some of the commercially available cobalt oxides are cobalt monoxide (CoO), cobalt oxide (Co2O3), and cobalt tetroxide (Co3O4) [31]. Most of the time, a mix of these three makes up the remaining cobalt oxides. There are many ways to get cobalt oxides with a higher valence, such as CoO2 and several compound structures for CoO3 [32,33]. Co3O4 crystal formations throughout many space groups. An antiferromagnetic phase transition occurs in this oxide. The cobalt core's valence oxides reflect light, and the surface glows due to its hybrid electrical arrangement. The intrinsic structure of spinel cobalt oxide is defined by octahedral coordination of carbon and tetrahedral coordination of cobalt dioxide [34]. Various physical properties, including ferroelectricity in d°-type oxides, high-temperature phenomena, enormous magnetoresistance in manganites, and superconductivity, have been uncovered through low-temperature studies of the structural features of Co3O4 nanoparticles during the past half-century. As a class of inorganic mineral materials, transition metal oxides have recently become a fascinating area of study and assessment. Regarding their magnetic and transport properties, cobalt oxides display a great deal of complexity in solid-state physics and solid-state chemistry. Cobalt oxides exhibit charge-ordering phenomena and several possible valences, such as Co2+, Co3+, and Co4+, in addition to intermediate valences. Moreover, its exceptional capacity to exhibit several forms of symmetry, including pyramidal, tetrahedral, and octahedral, enables the generation of diverse structures across different dimensions: 1D, 2D, or 3D, allowing for significant flexibility within the oxygen framework. An essential factor in influencing physical attributes is non-stoichiometric oxygen. Additional practical considerations include the electrical configuration of cobalt across various oxidation states and its magnetic characteristics in potential spin states: high, low, and intermediate. Cobalt oxides' magnetic characteristics and electrical conductivity are varied and substantial; each variant has distinct capabilities. They often include structurally complicated transitions, which may sometimes encompass phenomena of electronic phase separation [32–34]. Six oxygen atoms encircle the Co3+ ion, whereas four oxygen atoms encircle the Co2+ ion. The magnetic moments of Co2+ are aligned antiparallel. In Co3O4, which has a cubic spinel structure as determined by the B3PW91 hybrid functional, a comparison of the experimental and calculated values shows the following: equilibrium interatomic distances (Å) of Co2+ ̶ O = 1.95 (Å) and Co3+ ̶ O = 1.92 (Å), bulk modulus (B0) = 211, and its pressure derivative (B′0) = 4.7 [35]. Fig. 1 a-c shows the three natural forms of cobalt oxide: cobalt oxide, di-cobalt oxide, and tri-cobalt oxide II, III [36]. 3 Synthesis of cobalt oxide nanoparticles Different-sized and shaped cobalt oxide nanoparticles have different effects. Since cobalt oxide nanoparticles have many potential uses, controlling their size and shape during production is crucial. 3.1 Chemical synthesis Cobalt oxide nanoparticles are most often synthesized via chemical precipitation, typically calling for two reagents: a cobalt precursor and a precipitant solution [37]. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles are produced by combining and stirring a solution of cobalt precursor and precipitant, then centrifugation, drying to collect the precipitates and further heating. Nanoparticles of cobalt oxide were created by Javed et al. by reacting solutions of cobalt chloride with oxalic acid [38]. The spherical cobalt oxide nanoparticles were produced by Raman et al. using a simple method that included centrifuging a solution of sodium tartrate and cobalt chloride. The solution was stirred for 6 h at room temperature to get a precipitate. Afterward, the powder was dried and rinsed. It was then heated to 600 °C in an air-recirculating muffle furnace for two hours. As instructed, the stove kept running until the powder cooled to room temperature [39]. Moradpoor et al. created antibacterial cobalt oxide nanoparticles by amalgamating three varying amounts of cobalt oxide with potassium hydroxide in differing quantities, then mixing and stirring them for varying durations. The collected sediment underwent drying, followed by calcination, which helped in the nanoparticle composition of cobalt oxide [40]. Additionally, several researchers have employed cobalt oxide nanoparticles’ chemical precipitation methods to synthesize the particles [41–43]. An essential advantage of cobalt oxide nanoparticles’ chemical synthesis is that it is simple and practical. This is why this approach is so widely used to synthesize cobalt oxide nanoparticles. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles can also be synthesized through chemical precipitation methods, but it is clear that the step is energy intensive owing to the temperature that must be maintained. Furthermore, some reaction conditions may challenge specific biology labs trying to complete some preliminary work. Compared to a straightforward chemical reduction method that can be performed to make cobalt oxide nanoparticles at room temperature, chemical precipitation methods are less efficient. Kanwal et al. added cobalt chloride and NaBH4 to a trisodium citrate solution to synthesize cobalt oxide nanoparticles, continuously stirred the mixture, and controlled the pH at 8. The resulting powder was rinsed with ethanol and distilled water and then left to dry in air at room temperature for 24 h [44]. This procedure is easier to implement in cobalt biology laboratories and requires less energy for cobalt oxide nanoparticle synthesis. Nagal et al. synthesized nanostructured cobalt oxide Co3O4 in one step using a copolymer surfactant, referring to the structure as nano-berry shaped Co3O4 (Fig. 2 a). An alloyed cobalt oxide was self-prepared by first dissolving 0.12 M Co(NOₜ)ₖ•6H₂O into 10 mL of ultrapure water. The pH of the solution was raised to 9 by slowly adding sodium hydroxide 0.3 M solution. It was swirled using a magnetic mixer for 10 min to ensure the mixture was uniform. Fig. 2b indicates the ability of Co3O4 to be nanostructured after being transferred to the autoclave, where it was kept at a temperature of 180 for six hours whilst under a carefully controlled environment of temperature, pressure, and timing. With the reaction completed, the autoclave was cooled before the precipitate was centrifuged for ten minutes at 5000 rpm. The product underwent a drying process within a 60 °C environment for three washes with ultrapure water before being annealed for two hours at a temperature of 450 °C. An enzyme-free electrochemical sensor for uric acid was constructed by washing and polishing a glassy carbon electrode with ethanol, nitric acid, and ultrapure water solution. Cleansed GCEs were then implanted with a slurry containing the harvests of the Co3O4 nano-berry. For the slurry, 0.02 g of Co3O4 was added to 50 mL of 5 wt % Nafion binder and ultrasonicated for ten minutes. This was followed by casting 2 mL and 4 mL slurries on the GCEs before drying them at 60 °C for 12 h. This research focuses on the capabilities of nano-berry-shaped Co3O4 nanostructures in electrochemical sensors, particularly regarding the detection of uric acid [45]. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles, cobalt oxide spinel nanoparticles, and cobalt chloride undergo a thermal breakdown using sodium carbonate, which requires high temperature. A precursor for the cobalt oxide nanoparticles is obtained by spinning a mixture of cobalt chloride and sodium carbonate in a ratio of 1:1 for an hour. The precursor can then be transformed into cobalt oxide nanoparticles by calcining the precursor in an air-filled ceramic crucible at 300 degrees for two hours [46–48]. Template synthesis is a well-known and familiar way of fabricating cobalt oxide nanoparticles. Kim et al. used the apo horse spleen ferritin coreless protein as a template to synthesize the cobalt oxide nanoparticles. The concentration of metal atoms within the ferritin protein cage is diluted to create hollow cobalt oxide nanoparticles in an aqueous solution. These methods can produce biocompatible nanoparticles used in biological contexts [49]. When heated, immiscible fluids may undergo a series of reactions that result in nanoparticles: emulsion formation via surfactant action, nucleation in "microbubbles," and subsequent consolidation and agglomeration. By mixing bisdodecylamine cobalt dichloride, bishacylamine cobalt tetrachloride, and bishacylamine cobalt dichloride, the researchers Dogra et al. synthesized cobalt oxide nanoparticles. The cobalt oxide nanoparticles have promising antibacterial and anticancer characteristics [50]. Advantages of the microemulsion method include modifiable particle size, mild reaction settings, easy operation, simple experimental equipment, and cheap raw materials. It finds widespread use in the production of nanomaterials. In the study conducted by Chen et al., a typical synthesis process was employed to obtain Co3O4 NDs/NCN hybrids (Fig. 2c). To create a solid precursor with a pink color, a combination of 1 mmol of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), 0.25 g of glucose, and 2 g of NaCl was put into a ball mill and processed for 6 h at a frequency of 400 rpm. The next step was to anneal the precursor material in a nitrogen environment at 900 °C for 2 h. Next, in the annealing process, the result was rinsed with deionized water to eliminate any trace of the NaCl template. The next day, it was vacuum-dried. The result is a combination of Co3O4 NDs and NCN, which was successfully obtained [51]. In Naresh et al.’s research, some ZnCo3O4 nanostructures were prepared using a solvothermal method (Fig. 2d). A precursor solution consisted of 70 mL ethylene glycol, 0.5 g zinc acetate tetrahydrate Zn(CH3COOH)2·4H2O, 1.0 Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, 1.0 g urea. This was subjected to vigorous mixing for one hour to ensure homogeneity. Thereafter, the solution was added to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. It was subjected to solvothermal treatment at 140 °C for 6 h. Following the reaction, the material was washed with deionized water and ethanol to eliminate any leftover impurities. When the precipitate was dried at 80 °C for five hours, the ZnCo3O4 nanostructures became available. The material was further improved by calcining in an air environment at 400 °C for 2 h, increasing temperature at 3 °C/min. Guaranteeing completion of this final stage ensured the finalized step formed the desired nanostructure ZnCoO2 scaffold. Fig. 2d illustrates the working process of the solvothermal method via a schematic diagram [52]. In the study by Shu et al., coral-like Co/CoO/RGO hybrid aerogels were fabricated using a freeze-drying and thermal reduction approach, as schematically illustrated in Fig. 2e. The process began with assembling CCOH and graphene oxide (GO) into a porous, crosslinked 3D framework through hydrogen bonding, assisted by polyvinyl alcohol (PVA). After this step, thermal reduction treatment was applied, resulting in the formation of the Co/CoO/RGO hybrid aerogels [53]. 3.2 Chemical-physical synthesis Supercritical water hydrothermal synthesis is a chemical-physical approach that Dekkers et al. used to create cobalt oxide nanoparticles. The metal salt solution was first brought to room temperature by passing it through a preheating coil with water heated to around 400 °C. All three parameters; flow rate, temperature, and pressure; remained at 240 bar. After reaching the mixing point, the pressure was quickly brought down to ambient levels using the back pressure regulator. The cobalt oxide nanoparticles were finally obtained by centrifugation, washing, and drying [54]. There are several advantages to making nanoparticles using the supercritical hydrothermal synthesis technique. The dispersion range is constrained, and the nanoparticles' diameters are modifiable. In addition, there is less energy cost, and the preparation process is easy. The absence of organic solvents throughout the process is a significant plus for environmental sustainability. However, proper separation techniques are required to remove the reaction's product. In the study by Karuppiah et al., a highly efficient and long-durable LaMnO3@C- Co3O4 composite was introduced as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for both the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in alkaline media. The LaMnO3 was first synthesized using a simple co-precipitation method, followed by the preparation of the LaMnO3@C- Co3O4 composite via a solid-state ball-milling process, as detailed in Fig. 3 a. In Fig. 3b,c, a scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of the LaMnO3 sample reveals a uniform distribution of particles resembling nano or microspheres. Nevertheless, as shown by TEM (Fig. 3d,e) and the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) picture of the LaMnO3@CCo3O4 composite (Fig. 3b), the carbon and Co3O4 particles were evenly distributed or coated on the perovskite nanostructure. The TEM pictures of LaMnO3@CCo3O4 beautifully show the carbon black and Co3O4 nanosphere surface coating on top of the LaMnO3 [55]. 3.3 Physical synthesis Physical synthesis of nanoparticles, which involves creating cobalt oxide nanoparticles, is based on evaporating materials in a vacuum or inert gas using optical and electrical technologies. This allows for the formation of nanoparticles from atoms or molecules. When working with metal nanoparticles, ionic liquids may help control their shape, size, and crystal structure by acting as stabilizers or structure-directing agents. In a low-temperature anhydrous ionic liquid setting, cobalt oxide nanoparticles were synthesized using ozone, according to Schuster et al. [56]. The resultant nanoparticles had a restricted size range and an average dimension of 4 nm. Pulsed laser fragmentation was used by Yu et al., using a continuous water system to create cobalt oxide nanoparticles. As a long-lasting rigid template, spinel cobalt oxide was synthesized using a simple coffee grinds process. A mesoporous structure with particles of 8 nm in size was preserved throughout the manufacture of cobalt oxide using a mild reduction method [57]. An environmentally friendly method for producing active cobalt catalysts was developed, including synthesizing cobalt oxide nanoparticles in a flowing water system. 3.4 Green biosynthesis Because it uses less energy than traditional methods, in recent years’ biosynthesis of nanoparticles has gained significant traction and credibility. For various industries, scientists have biosynthesized cobalt oxide nanoparticles [58,59]. Biosynthesis is a simple, safe, and environmentally friendly way to make cobalt oxide nanoparticles that can do many different things. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles cannot be synthesized without plant extracts. Plants' abundant and non-toxic properties make plant-mediated synthesis of cobalt oxide nanoparticles a very attractive prospect for future medical uses. The pink cobalt chloride solution was mixed with twelve distinct fractions of plant extracts depending on solvents in a method developed by Hasan et al., who then used these extracts as stabilizers to create cobalt oxide nanoparticles [60]. Kiani et al. could synthesize cobalt oxide nanoparticles by reacting cobalt nitrate with Spanish sage. Furthermore, cobalt oxide nanoparticles were synthesized by Raeisi et al., utilizing plant extracts obtained from fresh rosemary leaves [61,62]. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles may be made using phytochemicals found in Rhamnus virgata leaf extract because of their reducing and stabilizing properties [63]. Bacteria might provide a source for nanoparticles, such as how plants produce them. The synthesis of cobalt oxide nanoparticles was accomplished using several bacterial strains. Cobalt oxide nanoparticles were synthesized using the Gram-positive Bacterium Bacillus subtilis. The process included adding NaBH4 for reduction after injecting CoCl2·6H2O into the bacillus solution. The cobalt oxide nanoparticles were successfully synthesized after a series of steps including centrifugation, washing, and drying [64]. Listeria also can potentially improve the properties of protein and mineral components; Allen et al. found this out [65]. One example is the creation of cobalt oxide nanoparticles. This method is less harmful to the environment than chemical processes, but it takes a long time and may be contaminated. Like bacteria, fungi are microbes that can produce cobalt oxide nanoparticles. In their study, Vijaya Nandan et al. extracted nanoparticles in the supernatant from a cobalt acetylacetonate solution by mixing the fungal biomass with it and stirring it under certain conditions [66]. This may make cobalt oxide nanoparticles between 20 and 27 nanometers in size by employing the sterile silk filtrate from Aspergillus brasiliensis ATCC 16,404 [67]. The method offers distinct benefits for producing cobalt oxide nanoparticles because the essential components can be readily obtained and separated. People have tried to synthesize chiral inorganic nanoparticles using biomolecules in the past. Using L-and D-Tyr-Tyr-Cys ligands, a chiral cobalt oxide nanoparticle factor of 0.01 in the UV–visible spectra was achieved by Kim et al. via their synthesis. An aqueous solution containing cobalt chloride, sodium citrate, and Tyr-Tyr-Cys was agitated at room temperature for thirty minutes. Nanoparticles of cobalt oxide were produced by injecting NABH4 and allowing the mixture to age for two hours while stirring at room temperature [68]. When thinking about potential biological uses for cobalt oxide nanoparticles, the most important thing is to figure out how to make them work. Further approaches for manufacturing cobalt oxide nanoparticles are being explored since current nanomedicine-based anticancer treatment strategies need precision targeting and strong selectivity towards cancer cells. Future applications of cobalt oxide nanoparticles in cancer treatment are anticipated to be enhanced by developing more efficient methods for fabricating these particles. 3.5 Producing cobalt nanoparticles sustainably by using plant extracts Compared to alternative physical or chemical processes, using natural plants to make cobalt nanoparticles is more practical, manageable, cheaper, and better for the environment [69]. Another benefit of using plants as a biological substrate is their abundance of critical phytochemicals. This means that chemicals, such as cobalt metal salts, may be used less often as reducing, capping, or stabilizing agents when making metal nanoparticles from their precursor solutions. As a result, this method is known as "green synthesis." Nitrate, acetate, and chloride of cobalt were added to the plant extracts at specific concentrations and volumes to create cobalt metal salts. The phytochemicals in the extracts may function as reducing, capping, and stabilizing agents throughout the process of creating CoO nanoparticles from the cobalt ions in the precursor solution. A muffle furnace may calcinate the plant extract and cobalt metal precursor reaction combination at a specific temperature in an inert or air-free atmosphere. The cobalt nanoparticles, which result from the calcination process, must be washed to remove any surface impurities. There is evidence that the phytochemicals present in the plant extract are more abundant than in the synthetic nanoparticles and that they serve as bioreactors, capping agents, and stabilizers [69–72,73]. Therefore, it is more difficult to accurately quantify plant extracts for nanoparticle production due to the lack of clarity around their phytochemical and antioxidant content. The specific selected plant parts and their concentration determine the phytochemicals and the resultant size of the synthesized nanoparticles. A more recent study has shown that various natural materials, such as plants and their constituents, have been used to synthesize cobalt nanoparticles. Some methods have elucidated certain phytochemicals' contributions towards the distinguishing formation of cobalt nanoparticles with unique features. The findings of Akhlaghi et al. regarding the elaboration of cobalt nanoparticles [74]. The next step was to anneal the mixture in the open air for two hours at 500 °C, after which the cobalt precursor was mixed with fenugreek leaf extract. The synthesized nanoparticles were characterized using various scientific methods, including transmission electron microscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, energy dispersive spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, energy dispersive spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy. Using eco-friendly materials like clove extracts and seeds from plants like Allium sativum and Coriandrum sativum, Asha et al. created cobalt oxide nanoparticles. The purity, surface morphology, and crystalline characteristics of the cobalt nanoparticles that were developed and fabricated were assessed using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and scanning electron microscopy energy dispersive spectroscopy [75]. Due to their high phenolic chemical content and various physiological capabilities, such as anti-inflammatory, antiviral, antibacterial, and fungicidal activities, walnut green hulls were used to produce cobalt nanoparticles in a different work by Mohammadi et al. [76]. As reducing agents and hydrogen donors, phenolic compounds are very reactive. To make cobalt nanoparticles, a 50 mL solution of cobalt nitrate (a cobalt metal precursor) and a 10 mL plant extract were cooked on a hot plate at 70 °C, which were an integral element of this study. Two hours of calcination at 600 °C was applied to the result of this process. No stabilizing agents or surfactants were employed during the process of making nanoparticles. According to the paper, the synthesized nanoparticles were evenly distributed, did not aggregate, and had a spherical shape with a size of 60 to 80 nm. The authors attributed this result primarily to the selected plant extract. The phytochemicals present in walnut green hull extract functioned as both reducing and stabilizing agents in the biosynthesis of cobalt nanoparticles from cobalt ion precursors. The resulting nanoparticles demonstrated superparamagnetic behavior, attributed to their saturation magnetization of 3 emu·g⁻1. This magnetic property facilitates the efficient separation of nanoparticles from aqueous media using an external magnetic field, offering a promising approach for the removal of contaminants from water while minimizing the risk of secondary pollution. Cobalt nanoparticles were produced by Rasheed et al. using Taraxacum officinale plant leaves. Flowering herbaceous medicinal plant T [77]. Officinale is rich in flavonoids (such as quercetin, chrysoeriol, and caffeic acid) and phenolic acids (such as caftaric, coumaric acid, and caffeic). According to TEM image analysis, the synthesized cobalt nanoparticles had a spherical shape, an average size of 50 to 100 nm, and were evenly distributed at about equal intervals. Researchers found that the plant extract's phytochemicals work as a protective shell around individual cobalt metal particles, reducing magnetic induction and keeping them at a nanoscale size. The stability and synthesis of cobalt metal ions into nanoparticles were attributed to phenols, proteins, acids, and polypeptides derived from plant extracts, according to experimental results for nanoparticle characterization by FTIR. Using a water-based cobalt nitrate solution, Sharma et al. synthesized CoO nanoparticles using a Calotropis gigantean plant leaf extract [78]. To extract the phytochemical components of the leaves, 100 g of washed leaves were boiled in 200 mL of deionized water. Following filtration, the resulting solution was subjected to continuous stirring with a magnetic stirrer to interact with cobalt nitrate. A deep brown paste consistency was achieved by continuously heating the reaction mixture at 60–80 °C. The cobalt nanoparticles were synthesized by calcining the resulting paste in an aerobic environment for 2 h at 400 °C. The cobalt nanoparticles had a defined spherical shape, which was further confirmed by scientists to have a surface area of 46.7 m² g−1, and a crystallite size between 50–80 nm. Furthermore, the researchers established that the synthetic nanoparticles showed higher catalytic activity in accelerating the burn rate of composite solid propellant than chemically synthesized cobalt nanoparticles. Thus, the researchers have discovered that the cobalt nanoparticles made from non-toxic materials could be catalytic constituents of dye-sensitized solar cells. In the research conducted by Aslam et al., cobalt oxide nanoparticles were synthesized using the cyanobacterial extract Nodosilinea nodulosa as a chelating agent, which makes the process more environmentally friendly [Fig. 4 a-e]. This process adds to the existing greener alternatives to traditional nanotechnology methods and is the first instance of this species being employed for nanoparticle synthesis. The synthesis of Co3O4 NPs was confirmed using X-ray diffraction, which showed a particle size of 41 nm, and UV-visible spectroscopy, which showed a peak at 453 nm. A host of in vitro studies were conducted to explore the potential therapeutic applications of Co3O4 NPs. The ability of the nanoparticles to impede the growth of bacteria and fungi was assessed. The maximum zone of inhibition was displayed by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, demonstrating the highest susceptibility, while Bacillus safensis showed the lowest. Fusarium oxysporum was the most susceptible fungus, having a maximum ZOI of 3 ± 0.04 µg/mL, whereas Aspergillus flavus had a lower ZOI of 2 ± 0.04 µg/mL. An LC₌₀ value of 498 µg/mL was obtained from the brine shrimp test, which was used to evaluate the cytotoxicity of the Co3O4 NPs. At higher doses (200 µg/mL), there was noticeable hemolytic activity, while the antioxidant test showed 60 % antioxidant activity at the exact dosage. Also, Co3O4 NPs weren't efficient against nuisance insects, including Rhyzopertha dominica, Sitophilus oryzae, and Tribolium castaneum. The effects of phytotoxicity were shown to be dose-dependent, meaning that larger doses had stronger impacts [79]. 4 Properties 4.1 Optical properties of cobalt oxides in electrocatalytic water splitting Cobalt-based oxides, including CoO, Co2O3, and Co3O4, are widely studied for their electrocatalytic properties, particularly in water-splitting reactions. The two key reactions in water splitting are the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions. The efficiency of these reactions is the fastest under an ideal electronic skeletal structure of the material, which bears importance to its optical features. The cobalt oxide's remarkable ability to participate in both the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions makes them debatable for electrocatalytic water splitting. These two hydrolytic reactions are the centre stage of our focus in this work [49]. In this subsection, we concentrate on the optical features that dictate the performance of cobalt oxides in these two reactions [80]. 4.1.1 Optical band gap and charge transfer in HER and OER The conduction and participation of electric current in the electrochemical reactions of a material are executed through its distinct band gap. In cobalt oxides, the optical band gap depends on the phase and structure of the oxide. The band gap is associated with electrical characteristics and the capacity of the material to be involved in charge transfer processes, which are fundamental to both HER and OER. CoO has an optical band gap of about 3.24 eV [81]. CoO is suitable for the hydrogen evolution reaction due to the presence of favorable electronic transitions that enable electron transfer. However, the band gap may affect its efficiency for oxygen evolution reaction since higher energy levels are usually needed for the oxygen evolution process. Another cobalt oxide used in electrocatalysis is Co3O4, which is widely used for OER. Co3O4 has band gaps of approximately 2.9 and 2.4 eV, corresponding to Co2+ and Co3+ oxidation states, respectively. These factors in the electronic structure are essential for the observed efficient OER activity [82]. Co3O4 with dual oxidation states of cobalt can have high catalytic activity for OER due to the generated multiple active sites for oxygen evolution. Recent research suggests that the band gaps of cobalt oxides can be modified through defect introduction, such as oxygen vacancies or doping with different elements. It has been demonstrated that incorporating oxygen vacancies into Co3O4 enhanced the HER and OER by narrowing the band gap. Oxygen vacancies help lower the band gap and serve as added active sites for both processes, thus improving the efficacy of charge transfer and intermediate adsorption, which is essential for both HER and OER [83]. 4.1.2 Optical transitions and catalytic activity for HER and OER In cobalt oxides, the optical transitions are associated with an electron transfer from the valence band to the conduction band, enabling charge transfer in electrocatalytic reactions (Fig. 5 ). These transitions can be classified as direct or indirect, and both determine the funneling of energy within the material that creates the mobile charge carriers needed for water splitting and photocatalysis processes [84]. In HER, Co3O4 and other cobalt oxide compounds have optical transitions, which are critical for charge separation with the electrolyte. Co3O4, for instance, has two major transitions around 2.4 eV and 2.9 eV, which are regarded as the electron transfer to the catalyst surface. The transitions result from the excitation of electrons within the cobalt oxide structure, which allows the catalyst to engage in the HER reaction process [82]. Co3O4 demonstrates exceptional effectiveness for OER due to the availability of multiple oxidation forms of cobalt (Co2+ and Co3+) in the structure. The Co3O4 optical transitions are also able to catalyze electron transfer, as well as intermediate adsorption, associated with OER. Often, these transitions are connected to the reduction of the overpotentials, which is essential for the efficiency of the water-splitting systems OER. Dopants can be introduced into cobalt oxide to alter the optical transitions and, therefore, the electrocatalytic activity. For instance, nickel and iron substitution in cobalt oxides enhances the mobility of the optical transitions, enhancing the charge transfer in both HER and OER. Also, the doping process may increase the ease of electron transitions by decreasing the band gap necessary for both reactions [85]. 4.1.3 Effect of surface structure on optical properties for HER and OER The surface structure of cobalt oxide materials is also essential for their optical properties, especially for their active sites for HER and OER. The surface area, crystallinity, and morphology could influence the material’s characteristics for light harvesting and charge separation in electrocatalytic processes. Cobalt oxide nanosheets, nanowires, and nanoparticles have better optical absorption than their bulk forms. These materials have a higher surface-to-volume ratio, leading to greater availability of active sites for catalytic processes. This increase in exposure to the electrolyte is advantageous for both HER and OER processes [86–88]. Furthermore, the optical properties of these nanostructures are improved due to the enhanced catalytic performance from increased active sites available for electron transfer [53]. Combining cobalt oxides with carbon-based materials such as graphene or reduced graphene oxide shows remarkable enhancement of cobalt oxides' optical properties and electrocatalytic activity. Hybridization with rGO improves light absorption and the charge transfer for both HER and OER. Including graphene helps to improve the long-term stability of cobalt oxide during water splitting and enhances its overall stability [89]. In the electrocatalytic water splitting process, the optical features of cobalt oxide materials are essential for their catalytic efficacy towards both oxygen and hydrogen evolution reactions. These parameters, such as band gap, charge optical transitions, and surface features, deeply influence the material’s charge transfer efficiency and cobalt oxide’s capability toward electrocatalysis. Improvement in optical properties owing to augmentations in defect engineering, doping, and nanostructuring has enabled an enhanced cobalt oxide performance for water-splitting electrocatalysis. Improving these optical properties would develop cost-efficient and stable cobalt-based electrocatalysts for sustainable energy harvesting, which is very appealing. 4.2 Electronic properties of cobalt oxides in electrocatalytic water splitting Cobalt oxides such as CoO, Co2O3, and Co3O4 are very active electrocatalysts for water splitting, particularly for oxygen and hydrogen evolution reactions. The Co3O4-based materials, in particular, are amenable to being modified with other metals, leading to an alteration in their electronic structure, in particular, oxidation states, defect structures, and surface modifications. Such electronic properties control the performance of the material for the reaction, more so overpotential and stability during the electrolysis and activity afterwards. 4.2.1 Electronic structure and catalytic activity for HER and OER Cobalt oxides' features, especially the electrodes' capacity to toggle between Co2+ and Co3+ oxidation states, are crucial for efficient causative activity in both OER and HER. These developments have increased the productivity of charge transfer and optimized intermediary adsorption related to electrocatalysis. Co3O4 has been extensively researched for OER precisely because of how it aids in the cyclical change of the oxidation state of cobalt from Co2+ to Co3+. This state of Co3O4 enables efficient oxygen evolution with low overpotential. Further, the OER performance of Co3O4 has also been shown to be improved by modifying its electronic structure through the introduction of oxygen vacancies or metal doping. The latest works have demonstrated that incorporating cobalt oxides with nickel or iron dopants is better, resulting in higher performance of electrocatalytic activity for both OER and HER due to improved electronic structure [90,91]. A catalyst for HER, which is highly effective, is CoO, with its Co2+ oxidation state being the most active of all. Hydrogen atoms bind favorably, and hence, the electronic structure of CoO is highly favourable. CoO constitutes an excellent candidate for hydrogen production through water splitting because it has demonstrated low overpotential for HER in alkaline media [57]. Recent attempts have been directed toward achieving better performance in HER by increasing the electronic conductivity and altering the active sites on CoO [92]. One necessary approach to modify the electronic structure of cobalt oxides is the presence of oxygen vacancies. These electronic states associated with the oxygen vacancies make charge transfer easier and allow better adsorption of the intermediates during HER and OER. The electronic properties of the cobalt oxide can be further enhanced by doping with other metals such as iron, nickel, and molybdenum, leading to improved electrocatalytic performance [93]. For example, cobalt oxides with nickel doping exhibited improved electronic conductivity and OER performance, thus becoming efficient electrocatalysts for water splitting [94]. Mechanism of OER (Fig. 6 a-d) and HER (Fig. 6e) shows the process how water splitting proceeds. 4.2.2 Defect engineering and surface modifications The cobalt oxides' electronic properties and electrocatalytic efficiency are crucially undermined by the surface chemistry, mainly the concentration of structural defects like oxygen vacancies. Vacancies created in the oxygen lattice increase the efficiency of the charge transfer and form active catalytic sites. Oxygen vacancies enhance the electrocatalytic activity of cobalt oxides. These vacancies serve as active sites for catalysis and increase the material's conductivity, which is vital for the HER and OER. It has been reported that the creation of oxygen vacancies improves the stability during electrolysis while reducing the overpotentials, resulting in a better performance for water splitting, for which cobalt oxides with oxygen vacancies are ideal. Recent studies have pointed out the necessity of vacancy engineering to improve cobalt-based electrocatalysts [97]. The surface modification of cobalt oxides by designing heterostructures with graphene or carbon nanostructures leads to increased electronic properties of the cobalt oxides. Such changes are important because they enhance both electrocatalytic activity and the efficiency of HER and OER by increasing the material's effective surface area and conductivity. Indeed, incorporating cobalt oxides with rGO or CNTs resulted in enhanced charge transfer and, consequently, improved electrocatalytic performance during water splitting owing to lower overpotentials and higher stability [98]. 4.2.3 Synergy in bifunctional catalysts for HER and OER Cobalt-based oxides are commonly found in bifunctional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, where they can simultaneously catalyze HER and OER. The materials have electronic structures, such as their capability to modify succedent adsorbate energies, which are important for efficient water splitting. Some recent research showed that when cobalt-based oxides were combined with other metals like Iron, Nickel and Molybdenum, they acted as very effective bifunctional catalysts for HER and OER. These materials have better electronic structures that permit rapid electron transport and optimized adsorptive intermediate and lower overpotentials for both reactions. For instance, cobalt-iron sulfides with low overpotentials and high stability in long-term electrolysis demonstrated excellent bifunctional activity (sulfides with cobalt-molybdenum oxides also demonstrate this quality) [90,99]. The presence of cobalt and nickel in different alloyed systems has been proven to enhance significantly the electronic features and the catalytic activity for both HER and OER. The alloyed system is formed due to the improvement in the electronic structure, which results from the shift of the d-band centre and the increased surface adsorption of the intermediate species. These systems have demonstrated excellent bifunctional performance, with low overpotentials and high stability for long-term electrolysis [100]. The electronic nature of cobalt oxides accounts for their activity as electrocatalysts for hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions. Such activity was achieved by incorporating defects, doping, and modifying the surface of these catalysts, leading to highly active and stable cobalt based electrocatalysts with low bifunctional activity for the overall water splitting. These achievements turn cobalt oxides into a viable candidate for large-scale hydrogen production utilizing electrochemical water splitting. 5 Mechanism of electrocatalysis to produce hydrogen 5.1 Electrocatalytic reaction thermodynamics The electrolytic water process, which seeks to generate hydrogen at the interface between electrodes and electrolytes, is the principal initiator of the electrocatalytic HER [101–103]. Hydrogen generating capacity is greatly affected by the electrolyte's pH level. An acidic electrolyte has a higher concentration of hydrogen ions, and there are mainly two steps to the electrocatalytic hydrogen generating process. The initial step is the Volmer reaction, also known as the discharge reaction, which comprises the electrode's electron-releasing mechanism and the adsorption of hydrogen atoms onto the electrode surface through the combination of electrolyte electrons and hydrogen ions [104]. Formula (1) depicts the first phase of the electrochemical reaction process. The subsequent stage of the reaction is determined by the concentration of hydrogen atoms in the solution and may be either the electrochemical desorption reaction, known as the Heyrovsky reaction, or the composite desorption reaction, known as the Tafel reaction. A large concentration of hydrogen atoms on an electrode causes them to combine, producing hydrogen gas that eventually escapes the surface. The Tafel response describes this occurrence. As the amount of hydrogen atoms absorbed decreases, the interface may undergo a reaction using the newly formed electrons and hydrogen ions, and gas hydrogen is produced. The electrodes' surfaces subsequently allow the gas to be adsorbed. This event is described in the Heyrovsky answer. For the Tafel reaction, see Formula (2); for the Heyrovsky reaction, see Formula (3) [105]. Hydrogen may be more easily produced in acidic environments due to the high concentration of hydronium ions. (1) Volmer Reaction Process ( Acidic conditions ) : H + + e − → H * (2) Tafel Reaction Process ( Acidic / Alkaline conditions ) : H * + H * → H 2 (3) Heyrovsky Reaction Process ( Acidic conditions ) : H * + H + + e − → H 2 The concentration of hydronium ions is relatively low in an alkaline electrolyte. Hydrogen ions are primarily produced when water dissociates; nevertheless, hydrogen synthesis is a two-step process that works differently in alkaline than in situations of acidity. The Volmer response is the first stage, the discharge reaction, in which water releases hydrogen atoms and acquires electrons to form hydroxide ions. The surface of the electrode is adsorbed with the obtained hydrogen atoms. Formula (4) illustrates the Volmer reaction process in an alkaline environment. Phase two of the reaction might be an electrochemical desorption reaction (the Heyrovsky reaction) or a composite desorption reaction (the Tafel reaction). The Tafel reaction works in the same way in acidic and alkaline environments. Adsorbed hydrogen atoms, water molecules, and freshly generated electrons combine in the Heyrovsky reaction to form hydroxide ions and hydrogen gas. Formula 2 and Formula 5 illustrate the Tafel reaction and the Heyrovsky reaction, respectively, in an alkaline environment. Hydrogen production is more difficult in environments with a high pH due to the low concentration of hydrogen ions. (4) Volmer Reaction Process ( Alkaline conditions ) : H 2 O + e − → O H − + H * (5) Heyrovsky Reaction Process ( Alkaline conditions ) : H * + H 2 O + e − → H 2 + O H − 1. Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption One process that may be reversed is the reversible adsorption and desorption of hydrogen atoms at the interface between the electrode and electrolyte. Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption determines the direction and magnitude of the reversible chemical process [106]. The electrode/electrolyte interface may gather a significant quantity of hydrogen atoms that have been adsorbed if the ΔGH* value is very negative. In the context of hydrogen desorption, an ideal ΔGH* value is positive. A reduced ability of the electrode/electrolyte interface to hold adsorbed hydrogen atoms, which hinders hydrogen generation, is indicated by a very positive ΔGH* value. To achieve optimum hydrogen production capabilities, the ΔGH* value must be zero. However, it is difficult to accomplish this in actual life. 2. Electrode potential (E) The electrolyte and electrode surfaces have different potentials; the electrochemical process is driven by this difference, which is called the electrode potential (E). The Nernst equation (Formula (6)) shows the connection between the electrolyte hydrogen content and the electrode potential. The value of the molar gas constant, R, is 8.314 J⋅mol⁻¹⋅K⁻¹. The quantity of electrons transported is denoted by z throughout the process. F, representing Faraday's law, is equal to 96,485 C⋅mol−1. "E*" indicates the standard electrode potential. Formula (7) demonstrates the link between ΔGH* and E, showing that the electrode potential is affected by the amount of electric charge and ΔGH*. The number of charges per unit of space and time is called the electric charge density. One way to measure electrocatalytic activity is by looking at the specific surface area and current density. (6) E = E − R T z F I n c ( H * ) c ( H + ) (7) − Δ G H * = n E F 5.2 Electrocatalytic reaction kinetics The electrocatalytic hydrogen generation process's reaction kinetics reveals the rate of hydrogen atom conversion into hydrogen gas on the electrode/electrolyte interface. The rate-limiting stage of the electrode reaction is critical due to the multi-step reactions occurring on the electrode/electrolyte interface. You can see the reaction kinetics of the electrocatalytic hydrogen generation process shown by the over potential, Tafel slope, and exchange current density. 1. Overpotential (η) The amount of electrode polarisation is indicated by the overpotential (η). Discordance between the applied electrode potential and the electrode potential as determined by thermodynamics is known as overpotential. A higher overpotential results in a more polarized electrode and a higher external electrode potential. Achieving sustainable energy development may be impeded by high levels of energy waste caused by elevated external potential. Therefore, a little overpotential is sufficient to achieve a high hydrogen production rate. 2. Tafel slope (b) To determine the electrode/electrolyte interface's charge transfer capability during hydrogen desorption, the Tafel slope reaction (b) is used. Overpotential and Tafel slope are correlated, as seen in Formula (8). (8) η = a + b l g | j | The Volmer reaction becomes the rate-limiting phase in the hydrogen evolution process when the Tafel slope reaches 120 mV⋅dec−1. Thus, the rate of hydrogen generation is mostly dictated by the electrolyte's capacity to convert hydrogen ions into hydrogen atoms. The Heyrovsky reaction becomes the step that limits the pace of the HER at a Tafel slope of 40 mV⋅ dec−1. H2 atoms combined with freshly formed electrons and hydrogen ions in acidic settings or water in basic conditions mostly affect the rate of hydrogen synthesis [107]. The Volmer-Tafel mechanism governs the development of hydrogen when the Tafel slope equals 30 mV⋅dec−1. The rate-limiting stage in hydrogen production is the Tafel reaction. The main factor that dictates the rate of hydrogen synthesis is probably only combining hydrogen atoms to make hydrogen gas. To study the rate of hydrogen creation, one must alter the Tafel slope, which is the rate-limiting step in the reaction that produces hydrogen [108]. 3. Exchange current density The exchange current density reveals the electrocatalyst's ability to transfer electrons and catalytic activity. The connection among the exchange current density, overpotential, and Tafel slope is shown in formulas 8 and 9. The charge transfer coefficient is represented by α. The catalyst's capacity to transport electrons and the pace at which it generates hydrogen is improved with a higher exchange current density. Therefore, a high exchange current density is necessary for efficient hydrogen production. CoO has shown noteworthy promise for hydrogen exploitation, particularly with other materials like Co, MXenes, and MoS2 that further boost its performance [115]. Recent progress has been directed towards optimizing CoO structures, such as core/shell nanowire arrays and hybrid composites, as well as improving surface area, conductivity, and catalytic activity. These materials demonstrate low overpotentials, high stability, and bifunctional catalytic activity for both HER and OER, which makes them appropriate for overall water-splitting applications. Other methods like doping, nanostructuring, and heterojunction formation have increased the electrocatalytic efficiency [116]. These innovations led to the development of highly efficient and stable CoO-based electrocatalysts that rival the performance of noble metal-based catalysts for water splitting. The Ni foam substrate grows into a scaffolded, non-linearly connected framework of Co at the center and CoO at the shell, which is a self-supported nanowire array at the top. Like the inner electrode, these outer electrodes are also self-standing, well-scaffolded, and very conductive. This architecture improves the material's electrochemical stability and conductivity, which are important for the efficient HER. The CoO shell has the strongest intrinsic catalytic activity, and the Co core possesses dependable electrical conductivity. The unique nanowire morphology of the material greatly enhances the surface area, which helps to improve reaction kinetics. The N-doped carbon layer helps in electron transfer and stabilizes the CoO, which prevents the deactivation of CoO. These materials offer several advantages, including their high stability, abundance, and cost-effectiveness, which make them an attractive alternative to more expensive precious metal catalysts like platinum. However, despite these advantages, Co3O4 materials still face challenges related to low conductivity and suboptimal catalytic activity, which can hinder their overall performance [135]. Transformations in Co3O4 through doping, hybridization, and oxygen vacancy creation have been the focus of research and development for improving electrocatalytic activity for the past few years. The review analyzed recent developments in Co3O4-supported materials for HER with an emphasis on integrating different structural strategies to achieve better stability and efficiency in catalysis [136]. Using Pt (platinum) nanoparticles within Co3O4 nanostructures is one of the most efficient approaches to increase the performance of Co3O4. This technique improves hydrogen evolution activity and decreases overpotential to an impressive 37 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm², which is much better than Co3O4 alone. The synergistic effects between Pt and Co3O4 play a crucial role, with Pt nanoparticles reducing the hydrogen adsorption energy on Co-active sites and improving electron conduction. These effects, supported by theoretical calculations, result in a marked increase in catalytic efficiency. The Pt-Co3O4 composite also shows superior stability, making it a promising material for large-scale industrial applications [137]. In another innovative approach, the surface characteristics of a NiFeP alloy are refined using microbiological techniques and subsequently decorated with Co3O4. This hybrid electrocatalyst, termed Co3O4@NiFeP-5/24 h, exhibits a porous 3D structure of intercrossed nanoparticles, enhancing electrolyte ion penetration and promoting efficient gas bubble release during the HER. A lowered Tafel slope of 98 mV/dec and a low overpotential of 106 mV at 10 mA/cm² are the outcomes of this design, suggesting rapid response kinetics [138]. The electrocatalytic activity in oxygen and hydrogen evolution reactions is increased with the creation of oxygen vacancies due to the doping of molybdenum into Co3O4. This Mo-Co3O4 catalyst can achieve an outstanding HER overpotential of 141 mv at 10 ma/cm² and remarkable efficiency when used for urea oxidation and OER. Oxygen vacancy and Mo addition greatly enhance the adsorption and activation of process intermediates, enhancing the catalytic efficiency. This approach to material design creates opportunities for developing highly efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts applicable to numerous electrochemical processes [139]. An additional tactic to improve the electrocatalytic activity of Co3O4 is to incorporate it with MoO2. A composite catalyst MoO2@Co3O4 efficiently conducted overall water splitting with overpotentials of 143 mV and 177 mV for OER and HER, respectively. The catalytical activity is remarkably enhanced due to the cooperative effect between MoO2 and Co3O4, which renders this composite material ideal for water splitting. Furthermore, the catalyst displayed superb durability by retaining its stability for over 23 h under alkaline electrolyte conditions [140]. The progress made in Co3O4-based electrocatalysts for HER is equally notable, especially in the doping, hybridization, and creation of oxygen vacancies strategy. Besides promoting catalytic activity, these approaches increase the material’s stability and endurance, therefore making them more applicable to industrial-scale hydrogen production endeavors. The relentless enhancement and fine-tuning of these materials are projected to be crucial in driving the development of sustainable energy technologies. Recent research has significantly enhanced their performance, making them highly competitive with precious metal catalysts [159]. The synthesized material using a green chemistry approach has an overpotential of 337 mV at 10 mA/cm² and 65 mV/dec Tafel slope, indicating good reaction and electron transfer kinetics. The Co3O4 CoO nanocomposite exhibits remarkable electrochemical stability and is essential for large-scale utilization. The CoO set on NiFe layered double hydroxide is known for high OER activity, having a 230 mV overpotential at 100 mA/cm². The combination of CoO and NiFe LDH facilitates high charge transfer and stability, resulting in effective and long-lasting OER efficacy. Wang et al. (2024) claimed that this heterostructure is beneficial for electrochemical stability and efficiency and thus can be used for commercial water-splitting systems [20]. In their 2024 publication, Zhu et al. described how Fe-doped CoO nanoparticles synthesized with laser assistance exhibited an overpotential of 548 mV at 1000 mA/cm^2 and remarkable long-term stability. The increase in the catalyst’s performance due to the added oxygen vacancies and Fe species, which is believed to be due to increased electron transfer and enhanced stability at high current densities, was an important finding. This paper in Electrochimica Acta laid the groundwork for CoO-based catalysts to be used in high-efficiency OER applications [161]. For the OER, the composite catalyst CoO@RuO2/Ti3C2−MXene achieved a strikingly low overpotential of 195 mV and a Tafel slope of 93 mV/dec, demonstrating rapid electron transfer and efficient catalysis. The synergistic effect between MXene, which has great electrical conductivity, and CoO and RuO2, which improves the oxygen adsorption step, results in superior performance in both acidic and alkaline solutions, as shown by Tran et al. (2024). In addition, the catalyst demonstrated excellent long-term stability, making it one of the most promising OER electrocatalysts [162]. In a different study, Du et al. The catalyst necessitated 230 mV of overpotential in the dark but remarkably only 170 mV under light, demonstrating the impact of light in increasing OER activity. This work also demonstrated the potential of CoO-based catalysts for photo-assisted water splitting, where combining CoO with NiFe LDH leads to improved efficiency [21]. Table 4 shows the comparison of CoO-based nanostructures for the OER. 6.4 Co3O4-based materials for OER Co3O4-based materials are gaining attention as electrocatalysts for the OER due to their high stability, excellent activity, and low cost. The composites of Co3O4 and AC that were created by Lima et al. exhibit a Tafel slope of 65.32 mV/dec and an overpotential of 325 mV at 10 mA/cm². The material is very stable electrochemically, keeping its performance for 8 h of continuous operation, and the better OER performance is due to oxygen vacancies, Co3+ ions, and the improved conductivity provided by the activated carbon support. The reduced charge transfer resistance and high double-layer capacitance further enhance its electrocatalytic performance. This catalyst outperforms many CoOx-based materials in OER performance due to the synergy between Co3O4 and carbon [173]. Chueh et al. studied the modification of Co3O4 with Sn, Sb, and Mn to enhance its stability and activity under acidic conditions. The Sn-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited the best performance, with an overpotential of 230 mV at 100 mA/cm². The catalyst showed excellent stability and durability, with current densities exceeding 100 mA/cm² in a polymer electrolyte membrane water electrolysis cell. The Sn-modified Co3O4 stabilizes the structure, preventing corrosion and dissolution during operation, making it a cost-effective and stable catalyst for acidic OER [174]. Zhao and Liang (2024) investigated the engineering of crystal facets in Co3O4 to enhance its oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity. Their study revealed that Co3O4 with mixed crystal facets demonstrated superior OER performance compared to Co3O4 with single or specific crystal facets. The improved catalytic activity was attributed to the increased active surface area and more favorable electronic structure facilitated by the mixed facets. The overpotential at 10 mA/cm² was 257 mV, and the material showed excellent stability for over 100 h. Co3+ species on the surface were responsible for the high OER activity, although their transformation to CoO2 led to dissolution and instability over time. Incorporating Ru into the Co3O4 surface formed a Co3O4/RuO2 heterostructure, which showed better performance with reduced overpotentials and enhanced durability [175]. In Zhao et al.'s (2024) work, they doped Co3O4 nanosheets with Ce single atoms, significantly enhancing the OER performance in acidic conditions. The overpotential was as low as 348 mV at 10 mA/cm², surpassing many non-noble metal electrocatalysts. The Ce doping improved the charge transfer and electronic structure of Co3O4, facilitating the OER process. The catalyst also showed great stability within a 0.5 M H2SO4 environment, beating all other non-noble electrocatalysts for OER. This study indicates that Ce-doped Co3O4 may be a promising candidate for non-expensive and effective OER catalysts [141]. Saddeler et al. (2024) created Co3O4@CoO core-shell nanoparticles for OER that had greater activity initially, but decreased with longer calcination times due to higher amounts of Co(III) cations. Their power depletion was 338 mV at 10 mA/cm² and their activity deteriorated over time. Chronopotentiometric tests showed that CoO nanoparticles had reduced OER activity after 18 h. The study demonstrates the importance of controlling the oxidation state of cobalt in Co3O4@CoO structures for long-term OER performance [176]. Tran et al. (2024) described a new composite material of Co3O4-RuO2/Ti3C2−MXene, producing remarkable OER results. The overpotential at 10 mA/cm² was 195 mV in acid media and 247 mV in alkaline with Tafel slopes of 93 mV/dec and 97 mV/dec for acid and alkaline conditions, respectively. The synergy between Co3O4 and RuO2, along with the high conductivity of Ti3C2−MXene, enhanced OER activity. This composite showed excellent stability under acidic and alkaline conditions, demonstrating multi-electron reaction kinetics [162]. These studies demonstrate that Co3O4-based materials, with various strategies such as doping, facet engineering, and hybridization, continue to offer impressive OER performance, making them competitive alternatives to precious metal-based catalysts in water electrolysis and other energy conversion applications. Ahmed et al. synthesized the Co3O4 nanostructure using Phyllanthus emblica fruit extract as a stabilizing agent by a straightforward chemical precipitation process. The fruit extract has bioactive chemicals that may promote the transformation of cobalt precursors into Co3O4 nanostructures. The form and dimensions of the Co3O4 nanostructure were regulated by modifying the reaction parameters, including the addition of varying quantities of amla extract. Materials with a high surface area are especially promising for facilitating the OER at low overpotentials in alkaline environments. This results from their enormous quantity of accessible active surface locations. Ultimately, the researcher used it for electrochemical OER activity in 1 M KOH, where the Co3O4/MoS2 catalyst exhibited the lowest overpotential of 213 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm², with Tafel slopes relative to its components: Co3O4 (405 mV), MoS2 (486 mV), IrO2 (354 mV), among others (Fig. 12 a-e). The enhanced electrochemical OER activity of the Co3O4/MoS2 compound may be ascribed to many causes. The regulated shape of the Co3O4 nanostructure offers an extensive surface area, augmenting the accessibility of active sites and improving catalytic efficacy. Secondly, the incorporation of Co3O4 nanostructures into the MoS2 matrix establishes a conducive surface for electron transfer, enhancing the charge transfer kinetics during the OER. Ultimately, the distinctive electrical and structural characteristics of MoS2, when coupled with the catalytic capabilities of Co3O4, have a synergistic effect that improves electrochemical performance [177]. In recent studies, several strategies have been employed to enhance the performance of Co3O4-based materials for the Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER). Lima et al. (2024) investigated Co3O4 composites with activated carbon (AC), achieving a low overpotential of 325 mV at 10 mA/cm² and excellent stability over 8 h of continuous operation. This was largely attributed to the synergy between Co3O4 and AC, which improved conductivity and reduced charge transfer resistance. In contrast, Chueh et al. (2024) focused on modifying Co3O4 with Sn, Sb, and Mn, with the Sn-Co3O4 catalyst outperforming others by achieving an overpotential of 230 mV at 100 mA/cm². Their work highlighted the importance of stability under acidic conditions, demonstrating that Sn modification prevented corrosion and dissolution, providing long-term durability. On the other hand, Zhao and Liang (2024) explored the role of crystal facet engineering in Co3O4, revealing that mixed crystal facets led to superior OER performance compared to single crystal facets. Their study emphasized the importance of increasing the active surface area and enhancing the electronic structure, although stability remained a concern as Co3O4 transformed to CoO2 over time, which led to dissolution. Additionally, Ce-doped Co3O4, as studied by Zhao et al. (2024), demonstrated remarkable improvement in OER performance with an overpotential of 348 mV at 10 mA/cm², surpassing many non-noble catalysts. This doping strategy was effective in improving charge transfer and electronic structure, making it a viable candidate for efficient and cost-effective catalysis. Finally, studies like those of Saddeler et al. (2024) and Tran et al. (2024) examined hybrid Co3O4 composites, including Co3O4@CoO core-shell structures and Co3O4-RuO2/Ti3C2−MXene, which displayed outstanding OER performance with lower overpotentials and enhanced durability. Overall, while each approach presents a unique advantage, whether in stability, activity, or cost-effectiveness, these studies collectively highlight the diverse strategies being explored to optimize Co3O4-based materials for OER applications. Table 5 shows the comparison of Co3O4-based nanostructures for the oxygen evolution reaction. 7 Conclusion The cobalt oxide (CoO) and cobalt spinel oxide (Co3O4) materials are gaining significant attention in electrocatalysis, particularly for their applications in oxygen evolution reactions and hydrogen evolution reactions, critical steps for energy conversion technologies like water splitting. Throughout the review, it is clear that both materials offer substantial advantages in terms of low cost, abundance, and catalytic activity. Co3O4 has demonstrated excellent stability and high OER performance, with catalysts like Co3O4@RuO2 and Co3O4/MXene composites achieving overpotentials as low as 195 mV. Important studies have optimized the structural features of these materials with oxygen vacancies and hybrid catalyst formation. For instance, combining CoO with NiFe LDH increases the OER activity by achieving overpotentials higher than 230 mV. Doping with metals such as Ce, Fe, Ru, and others has also been shown to remarkably increase the electronic structure stability of these oxides, which is highly energetic. In particular, the composite of Co3O4 and RuO2 has been shown to lower OER and HER overpotentials, making it promising for commercial use. Advanced characterization techniques, such as electrochemical impedance spectroscopy coupled with Tafel slope analysis, deepened the understanding of charge transfer processes and how structural and chemical changes affect electrocatalytic activity. The addition of heterostructures, like Co3O4@CoO, also displays greater electrochemical stability and efficiency, which makes these materials competitive with precious metals catalysts. In summary, although CoO and Co3O4 materials can reasonably push the boundaries of electrocatalysis, further optimization of the synthesis methods and long-term stability enhancement and scale-up routines need to be studied for these materials to be commercially available in sustainable energy systems. The successful development of these cobalt oxide-based materials could significantly contribute to realizing efficient and low-cost energy conversion technologies. The future aspects • The atomic-level design of CoO and Co3O4 structures holds great potential for optimizing their electrocatalytic performance. Future research should focus on controlling the atomic scale's crystallinity, defect sites, and grain boundaries. Atomic layer deposition and molecular beam epitaxy can be utilized to precisely control atomic arrangements, leading to enhanced catalytic sites and more efficient electron flow during OER and HER processes. • The electronic structure of CoO and Co3O4 is critical in determining their catalytic efficiency. Advanced quantum mechanical simulations can aid in identifying the optimal oxidation states and electron density distributions of cobalt ions. Tailoring the local electronic environment via doping (e.g., with transition metals such as Mo or W) or creating CoO/ Co3O4 heterojunctions can further tune their electronic properties, improving the activation energy and enhancing reaction kinetics. • Integrating operando spectroscopy techniques such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and Raman spectroscopy will allow for real-time tracking of structural and electronic changes under operational conditions. These methods will provide critical insights into how CoO and Co3O4 catalysts evolve during catalysis, enabling the design of more stable materials by observing degradation pathways and optimizing surface reaction mechanisms. • Developing multi-dimensional heterostructures by integrating CoO and Co3O4 with advanced 2D materials (e.g., graphene, MoS2, and MXenes) or conductive ceramics will create efficient charge transport pathways and increase the catalyst's active surface area. • The manipulation of charge carrier density in CoO and Co3O4 is crucial for enhancing their electrocatalytic properties. Techniques like doping with metal ions (Ni, Fe, or Zn) or non-metallic elements (N, P, and S) can increase the charge carrier concentration, thus lowering the overpotential for both HER and OER. Dynamic modulation of charge carriers through electrochemical treatments (e.g., cyclic voltammetry or potentiostatic polarization) can optimize the catalyst’s performance during continuous operations. • Long-term stability and activity are vital for CoO and Co3O4materials in practical applications. Future research could explore integrating electrochemical cycling with thermochemical processes (such as annealing or surface oxidation/reduction) to regenerate the catalyst and maintain its active state over extended periods. Hybrid electrochemical-thermal cycles could potentially prevent catalyst deactivation and enhance the longevity of CoO/ Co3O4 in real-world devices like electrolyzers and fuel cells. • The application of machine learning algorithms in the design of CoO and Co3O4 electrocatalysts is emerging as a powerful tool for optimizing material properties. High-throughput screening methods powered by machine learning can predict the most effective doping strategies, identify optimal catalysts with lower overpotentials, and optimize synthesis conditions. Machine learning can also accelerate the discovery of new CoO/ Co3O4 composite systems by identifying previously unexplored material combinations. • Integration into Scalable, High-Performance Devices: The practical implementation of CoO and Co3O4 catalysts in large-scale energy conversion systems requires their integration into scalable, efficient devices. Future research should focus on designing large-area electrocatalytic electrodes with minimal catalyst loading, ensuring high performance while maintaining low-cost manufacturing processes. This involves optimizing catalyst morphology, support materials, and electrode architecture to enhance the mass transport of reactants and reduce resistance in industrial electrolyzers, fuel cells, and batteries. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt oxides, CoO and Co3O4, have become important electrocatalysts for energy conversion and storage systems, especially in the processes of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Their argument stems from their low cost, high stability, and ability to perform rapid charge transfer, making them excellent substitutes for noble metal-based catalysts. In this review, CoO and Co3O4 are analyzed from the structural, electronic, and catalytic viewpoints, focusing on their latest design and optimization efforts. The influence of defects, doping, and hybridization with carbon-based supports and metal additives on catalytic activity and stability is highlighted. Besides, the review discusses the influences of oxygen vacancies, cobalt ions in mixed-valence states, and heterostructures on the performance of the materials as a whole. The mechanisms of OER and HER on cobalt oxide-based catalysts are also discussed, emphasizing the electronic structure and reaction pathways these processes involve. The review is supposed to shed light on the processes of manually constructing composite catalysts by integrating CoO and Co3O4 with other materials, so the final products would have differed and enhanced electrocatalytic activity. The review concludes with an outlook on future directions for the development of CoO and Co3O4-based electrocatalysts, including the challenges associated with scaling up their synthesis for industrial applications and the need for further advancements in material engineering to optimize their performance in energy-related processes.
